intro: Pseudognaphalium roseum, commonly known as the rose-gold everlasting, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its compact, mat-forming growth habit. The plant produces small, pinkish to reddish flowers that are typically clustered in dense, spherical heads. Its foliage consists of narrow, gray-green leaves that are covered in fine hairs, contributing to its drought-tolerant nature. Pseudognaphalium roseum is often used in floral arrangements due to its long-lasting blooms and attractive appearance.
